Award.AwardTitle: Generate Glucose-Responsive, Insulin-Producing Cells from Human Embryonic Stem Cells in 3D Cultures

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-0756455
Ye

The objectives of this project are to develop a 3D human embryonic stem (hES) cell differentiation system and to elucidate the mechanisms of human pancreatogenesis through gene expression profiling and lineage tracing experiments. The specific aims are: (1) Establish a 3D collagen scaffolding hES cell culture system and demonstrate the generation of glucose-responsive, insulin-producing cells from hES cells in 3D cultures, and (2) Characterize the lineage-specific differentiation of hES cells into cells in 3D cultures. Initial studies will focus on in vitro experiments and subsequent studies will be designed to characterize in vivo functions of pancreatic cells in diabetic animal models through islet transplantation. Knowledge gained from these studies will be utilized to design a 3D culture system for directing the differentiation of hES cell into glucose-responsive and insulin-producing cells for islet transplantation. This is the next step to achieving the PI's long-term career goal of using 3D cultures to gain an understanding of biological behaviors of hES cells in 3D environments, which, in turn, will allow the designing of various 3D culture systems to direct lineage-specific hES cell differentiation into a variety of therapeutic cells for cell-based therapy. Findings from this work will offer new insights into hES cell biology, especially mechanisms that govern ES cell differentiation, proliferation, adhesion, migration, etc. in a 3D microenvironment. Technologies developed through this project will offer renewable cell sources for islet transplantation that can restore near-physiological insulin secretion capacity in type-1 or later stage type-2 diabetic patients. This project will also provide excellent opportunities for education and training of undergraduate and graduate students in stem cell engineering and regenerative medicine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human pluripotent stem cells (HPSCs), including embryonic stem cells (hESCs) and induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs), are promising cell sources with the potential for revolutionizing disease treatment. It is expected that many incurable diseases such as diabetes, cancers, and Alzheimer’s disease can be eventually cured using stem cells. Thus, they are an invaluable resource for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine.

This project focused on the development of a 3D stem cell differentiation system to direct hESC differentiation into glucose-responsive, insulin-secreting cells for diabetes treatment. Throughout the implementation of this research project, we demonstrated that glucose-responsive insulin-secreting islet beta-cells can be produced from the directed differentiation of hESCs in a three-dimensional (3D) collagen-based scaffold culture. Compared to a traditional 2D culture that uses tissue culture plate, a 3D culture approach mimicking the microenvironment in the body significantly promotes the effectiveness of beta-cell generation from hESC differentiation.

In addition, we also showed the importance of the microenvironment for HPSCs adhesion, expansion, and lineage-specific differentiation. Our experimental results suggest that a porous membrane substrate and/or a 3D extracellular matrix (ECM)-scaffold offer better tissue niches for hESC attachment, proliferation, and differentiation. Compared with hESCs grown on a polystyrene surface, those grown on membrane substrates have a considerably shorter doubling time. Global gene expression analysis revealed upregulated expressions of a number of ECM and cell adhesion molecules in hESCs grown on membrane substrates. Furthermore, an enhanced nuclear translocation of beta-catenin was detected in these cells. These observations suggested the augmentation of Wnt signaling in hESCs grown on membrane substrates.

Additionally, we determined the mechanical properties of soft tissue scaffolds by atomic force microscopy (AFM) nanoindentation. Usually, the determination of the mechanical properties of a hard scaffold is relatively straightforward. However, the mechanical testing of a soft tissue scaffold poses significant challenges due in part to its fragility. Thus, we developed a new technology for characterizing the stiffness and elastic modulus of a soft scaffold through AFM nanoindentation. Using collagen–chitosan hydrogel scaffolds as model soft tissue scaffolds, we demonstrated the feasibility of using AFM nanoindentation to determine the force curve of a soft tissue scaffold. This approach offers a new tool to understand cell fate regulation induced by the physiochemical cues of tissue scaffolds.

Four graduate students and nine undergraduate students, including four students from underrepresented groups such as African American, were trained throughout the project. The undergraduate students were initially teamed up with graduate students, and then later proceeded to work independently on their research projects. Six undergraduate students completed their honors thesis based on these research works. Two undergraduate students presented their research works in national conferences. Three undergraduate students received Honors College Research Award and two undergraduate students received Undergraduate Research Fellowship Award from the Arkansas Department of Higher Education.

In summary, the outcomes of the project include both scientific achievements and educational activities. One book, six peer-reviewed papers, one book chapter, and one invention disclosure were published. The research work was also disseminated at international and national conferences.
